questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient with a history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset severe headache, vomiting, and confusion. Neurological examination reveals signs of meningeal irritation, and the patient's Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score is 13. A non-contrast CT scan of the brain is performed as the initial imaging investigation. CT Findings: The non-contrast CT scan of the brain reveals an asymmetric, hyperdense lesion in the left frontal lobe. The Hounsfield unit (HU) value of the lesion is measured to be +65.

A 55-year-old male with a history of chronic alcohol abuse presents to the emergency department with complaints of weakness in all four limbs and difficulty speaking. The patient is confused and disoriented. The initial blood tests reveal hyponatremia. The neurological symptoms progressively worsen over the next 24 hours. RADIOLOGY Findings:

options.label: A
options.text: Administration of intravenous fluids with normal saline

options.label: C
options.text: Rapid correction of hyponatremia with hypertonic saline

questions.correct_answer: C. Rapid correction of hyponatremia with hypertonic saline

questions.text: A 12-year-old child presents with complaints of chronic headaches, visual disturbances, and growth retardation over the past few months. The child's parents also mention an increased frequency of urination and excessive thirst. Neurological examination reveals bitemporal hemianopia. There are no other focal neurological deficits. A CT scan of the brain is performed, revealing a well-defined, lobulated, cystic lesion with irregular calcifications in the suprasellar region, compressing the optic chiasm.

options.label: A
options.text: Infiltrative glioma with diverse cell types

options.label: B
options.text: Embryonal CNS tumor with extensive leptomeningeal dissemination

options.label: C
options.text: Rathke's cleft cyst with solid mural nodule

options.label: E
options.text: Pineal gland cyst with enhancing nodule

questions.text: Patient Profile: Name: Raju Age: 25 years Gender: Male Clinical Presentation: Raju, a 25-year-old male presents with a new onset of symptoms. He reports experiencing progressive hearing loss in his left ear and episodes of dizziness over the past few months. On examination, he demonstrates left-sided sensorineural hearing loss, subtle facial weakness on the left side, and an unsteady gait. He was a diagnosed patient of NF-2. Question: A normal CT scan is given. Find the site where lesion is most likely to be present.

Patient Profile: Name: Amita Age: 35 years Gender: Female Chief Complaint: Double vision and drooping of the right eyelid Clinical Presentation: Amita, a 35-year-old female, presents to the ophthalmology clinic with complaints of double vision (diplopia) and a noticeable drooping of her right eyelid (ptosis). She reports that these symptoms appeared suddenly and have been getting worse over the past two days. Anna also mentions experiencing a severe headache on the same side as the eye symptoms. On examination, her right eye is slightly deviated downward and outward, and she has difficulty moving it upward, downward, and inward. Pupils are equal in size and react normally to light. Question: Based on the clinical presentation, where is the most likely location of involved cranial nerve?

Patient Profile: Name: Mohanbhai Age: 50 years Gender: Male Chief Complaint: Memory problems and disorientation Clinical Presentation: Mohanbhai, a 50-year-old male, presents with memory problems and disorientation. He has difficulty recalling recent events, misplaces items, and feels lost in familiar places. There is no history of head trauma or neurological disorders.

Case: A 45-year-old male patient presented to the neurology clinic with a history of chronic alcohol abuse. He complained of persistent confusion, memory deficits, and difficulty in walking. Upon examination, the patient displayed signs of cognitive impairment, gait disturbances, and bilateral upper motor neuron facial palsy. Brain imaging revealed characteristic findings. Based on the presentation, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 45-year-old male with a history of hypertension presents to the emergency department after a fall from a ladder. He was initially conscious but has now become lethargic and confused. On examination, his Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score is 12 (E3, V4, M5). A head CT scan is promptly ordered, revealing a well-defined, biconvex, hyperdense lesion in the temporal region. The lesion is causing a mass effect with a midline shift. The falx cerebri is displaced, and there is compression of the lateral ventricle on the affected side. The cerebral cortex underlying the lesion appears to be compressed but not significantly displaced. Statements: A) There is blood collection between duramatter and arachnoid. B) Lucid interval is generally present in such cases. C) Blood can cross midline in such cases. D) Blood can cross sutures in such cases. E) Anatomical landmark for the involved vessel is found at the H-shaped junction of the frontal, sphenoid, parietal and the squamous part of temporal bone. Correct statements are?

Case Scenario: A 6-month-old infant was brought to the emergency department by his parents with complaints of altered consciousness and difficulty in breathing. The parents reported that the child had been crying excessively for the past few days and appeared more irritable than usual. On examination, the infant is found to have retinal hemorrhages. There are no signs of external injuries or other medical conditions. The parents deny any history of accidental trauma or falls. CT Scan of the infant is done and is provided below. Question: What is the most likely cause of these findings in this infant?

Case Scenario: A 55-year-old male presented to the emergency department with a sudden severe headache described as "the worst headache of his life." He has no significant past medical history, and there was no history of recent trauma. On examination, he appears distressed, and his blood pressure is 160/90 mmHg. Neurological examination reveals neck stiffness, bilateral pupils of equal size and reactivity, and no focal neurological deficits. A diagnosis of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) is suspected. Which of the following radiological investigations would be most appropriate to confirm the diagnosis and assess the extent of the SAH?
questions.correct_answer: B. Computed Tomography (CT) Scan without contrast

questions.text: Case Scenario: A 72-year-old female patient presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of severe headache, confusion, and right-sided weakness. The patient has a past medical history of hypertension and occasional migraines. Her family reports that she has been experiencing recurrent memory lapses and forgetfulness over the past few months. On neurological examination, the patient is found to have right-sided hemiparesis (weakness) and a decreased level of consciousness. Based on the clinical presentation and imaging findings, which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of the patient's lobar hematoma?

Case Scenario: Mr. Venkatesh, a 62-year-old male, presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset weakness on his right side. The weakness is more pronounced in his arm and leg, and he has difficulty walking. His medical history is significant for hypertension, for which he takes antihypertensive medications irregularly. His blood pressure on admission is 160/100 mmHg. The rest of his medical history is unremarkable. On examination, Mr. Venkatesh is conscious and oriented. His speech is normal, and there are no signs of facial weakness or asymmetry. However, he has right-sided hemiparesis, and his right arm and leg exhibit increased tone and reflexes. Sensory examination is unremarkable, and cranial nerves are intact. There are no signs of cerebellar dysfunction. Based on the clinical presentation and imaging findings, what is the most likely cause of Mr. Venkatesh's lacunar infarct?
questions.correct_answer: C. Lipohyalinosis of small penetrating arteries

questions.text: A 55-year-old female patient presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset severe headache, confusion, and left-sided weakness. The patient has a past medical history of hypertension and diabetes. Upon physical examination, the patient's blood pressure is elevated (180/100 mmHg), and she has weakness in her left arm and leg. A non-contrast CT scan of the head is performed. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Case Description: A 65-year-old male with a history of hypertension and diabetes presents to the emergency department with sudden onset weakness on the right side of his body and slurred speech that started 2 hours ago. The neurological examination reveals right-sided hemiparesis and mild facial droop. A brain CT scan is performed immediately. Question: Based on the provided clinical scenario and radiological findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?

A 28-year-old female presents to the emergency department with a severe headache and altered mental status. Neurological examination reveals papilledema and signs of increased intracranial pressure. Further investigation, including brain imaging is done. Which of the following factors is most likely to be implicated in the etiology of this condition?

Case: Amit, a 65-year-old male with a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and recent prolonged immobilization following a hip surgery, presents to the emergency department with sudden onset shortness of breath, chest pain, and mild cough. His vital signs reveal a heart rate of 110 bpm, respiratory rate of 26 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 91% on room air. The physical examination shows tachypnea and mild crackles on auscultation of the lung bases. In the X-ray findings, which of the following is NOT typically associated with the patient’s condition?

Vipul, a 62-year-old male, presents to the emergency department with severe, tearing chest pain that radiates to his back. He describes the pain as sudden in onset and rates it 10/10 in intensity. He has a history of hypertension and smoking. On physical examination, his blood pressure is 190/100 mmHg, heart rate is 110 bpm, and he appears anxious and diaphoretic. Radiological investigations are done to find the cause. Which of the following statements are false regarding the patient’s condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Hypertension can be the aetiology behind this

options.label: B
options.text: In a hemodynamically unstable patient, we can do a bed side trans-oesophageal echocardiogram.

options.label: C
options.text: Immediate surgical intervention is always required in such type of cases.

options.label: D
options.text: The pathology is lying in the descending aorta.

questions.correct_answer: C. Immediate surgical intervention is always required in such type of cases.

questions.text: Case Scenario: A 55-year-old male presents to the emergency department with severe pain and swelling in his right big toe. He describes the pain as sudden and excruciating, which has progressively worsened over the past 24 hours. He denies any history of trauma to the toe. His medical history includes hypertension and obesity. On examination, the affected joint is warm, erythematous, and extremely tender to touch. His vital signs are within normal limits. Laboratory tests reveal an elevated serum uric acid level. Based on the clinical presentation and laboratory findings, which imaging modality is most appropriate for further evaluation of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Non-Contrast Computed Tomography (NCCT) of the right foot

options.label: C
options.text: Multi-Detector Computed Tomography (MDCT) of the right foot

options.label: D
options.text: Spectral CT of the right foot

questions.correct_answer: D. Spectral CT of the right foot

questions.text: Patient Presentation: A 2-day-old male infant presents with bilious vomiting, abdominal distension, and failure to pass meconium. Physical examination reveals tenderness in the right lower quadrant and absence of bowel sounds. Patient is a known case of cystic fibrosis. X-ray of patient is done to evaluate further. Question: What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Surgical exploration and resection of the affected bowel segment.
